Award.AwardTitle: Undergraduate Sounding Rocket Field School Training Workshop at the Andoya Space Center in Northern Norway: Andenes, Norway - Fall 2018 and Winter 2019
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the travel of two University of Iowa (UI) undergraduate students and two UI faculty lecturers to attend an international undergraduate student sounding rocket field school called CaNoRock that is a week-long workshop based upon collaboration between the Andoya Space Center and seven Canadian and Norwegian Universities. The two UI professors will participate in the development of the geospace curriculum at the Andoya Rocket Range by teaching regular classes and helping to support the student rocket experiment preparations. In addition to these lectures, the workshop would focus upon hands-on student rocket activities to help train students while introducing them to the possibilities of graduate study or the prospects of a career in the aerospace industry. The primary project objectives are aimed at increasing awareness of US educational opportunities for space research activities and experimental rocket research. Eventually, it is expected that this collaboration would be developed into a more extensive activity that would include participation by students from other US educational institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Undergraduate Sounding Rocket Field School program uses a hands-on instruction in the use of rockets for scientific research as a highly visible talent magnet to attract undergraduate students to space related graduate studies and the aerospace industry. For each school, an international team of students from Norway, Canada, and the USA travel the Andoya Space Center and undertake a complete, but scaled down, sounding rocket campaign. This allows the course to cover all the phases of an experimental space physics mission compressed into five days. This grant supported the University of Iowa's participation - seven undergraduate students and two faculty instructors participated in the weeklong field schools.

Student feedback on the course demonstrated its effectiveness both as a teaching tool and as a "truly life-changing" formative career experience. Students consistently remarked on the hands-on nature of the course, and the experience of building instruments, integrating them on a rocket, launching the rocket, and then getting to analyze their own data. For example, one team "was able to determine the actual flight trajectory parameters of the rocket by combining data from multiple sensors and compare these results with our previously run simulations". Some refinements were made to the course based on student feedback including the addition of online background material that students complete in advance to help them prepare for the intense week-long program.

The students who participated in the program continue to be successful in a variety of space related activities such as: undergraduate research projects involving NASA missions (Halosat/MAVEN), applying to and completing graduate school, co-authorship on peer reviewed scientific papers, and even working as a professional engineer for hardware on the forthcoming NASA TRACERS SMEX satellite mission. Their participation in the school and their stories when they returned were widely covered by local media.

Many of the lessons learned from the Undergraduate Sounding Rocket Field School have been adapted in the creation of a new course at the University of Iowa titled "PHYS:5905 The Edge of Space: Mission and Instrument Design for Spaceflight". The course uses a similar hands-on project driven approach but replaces the rocket with a high-altitude balloon provided by a collaboration with Iowa State University. This new course complements the sounding rocket field school - as a full semester course it can go into further detail and as an on-campus course it is lower cost and accessible to more students. An ideal future collaboration would be for sophisticated instruments developed through the Edge of Space course to be tested on the high-altitude balloon and then taken to the Field School to be flown on a rocket.

Overall, the Undergraduate Sounding Rocket Field School was highly effective in attracting undergraduate students to space research an industry and helped enable the create of how space curriculum at the University of Iowa. One student remarked that the Rocket Field School "really opened my eyes to the world of Space Physics and now I can't stop thinking about how I can do this for the rest of my life".
